text:
Marble Hill Ave, south from Kingsbridge to 228th Street, showing Spuyten Duyvil Creek in the foreground.

March 28, 1906.

Brown Brothers.

Marble Hill Avenue, adjoining the N.W. corner of West 228th Street. This house was razed between 1916 adn 1925 and stood directly in rear of the apartment house now (1939) bearing No. 157 West 255th Street.

The thoroughfare in the foreground is the old Kingsbridge Road which on the Manhattan side of the former Harlem River bed became Marble Hill Avenue. Note the declivity at the rear of the house indicating the creek. On the right are buildings on the Bronx shore; the larger of which is St. Johns Roman Catholic Church. This stands on Kingsbridge Avenue between 230th and 231st Streets.

Views 2 and 3 show various details; the privy vault in yard, and a rubber water supply from pump there to a second story.

About 1907
Views: 1-2-3

Gift of Committee on Housing
Charity Organization Society

View 1: Neg. No. 81
View 2: Neg No. 82
View 3: Neg No. 83

West 228th Street, south side, east from and including Marble Hill Ave., showing at the S.E. corner of same St. Stephens M.E. Church. In the background appears the elevated structure of the west side I.R.T. subway on Broadway. Buildings, faintly outlined across same are in the Borough of the Bronx. The 2 1/2 story frame house seen on the right is No. 96 Marble Hill Ave.

P.L. Sperr
October 26, 1927

St. Stephen's Methodist Episcopal Church, 228th Street at the S.E. corner of Marble Hill Ave.
